article.description: Dahntay Jones matched his career high with 22 points and Daniel Ewing added a career-best 19 as the Blue Devils overcame a poor outing from the foul line to beat a physical Georgetown team 93-86 Wednesday night.
article.headline: Blue Devils' 15-1 run in second half turns game
article.linkText: No. 1 Duke passes Hoyas' test to remain perfect
article.story: DURHAM, N.C. (AP) -- After a relatively weak schedule to start the season, No. 1 Duke needed a game against a team like Georgetown -- a physical, fast, pressing squad that didn't back down in Cameron Indoor Stadium. The young Blue Devils took the Hoyas' best shot and came out on top Wednesday night as Dahntay Jones matched his career high with 22 points and Daniel Ewing added a career-best 19 in a 93-86 victory. "This Georgetown team is real quick and they play their hearts out,'' Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski said. "I love Georgetown's team. That's why I'm so pleased with this win because we beat a really good team. "We knew from the start this was going to be a different year than we've had for a long time here, but it could be a real fun year. So far, it's been excellent because of these kids.'' Duke (10-0) managed just five assists on 17 first-half baskets, but began sharing the ball during a 15-1 second-half run that turned the game in its favor. "The offense was really stale in the first half and guys just weren't moving around,'' said J.J. Redick, who added 13 points. "There was a lot of one-on-one and then in the second half Chris (Duhon) starting working his magic with that pick-and-roll up top.'' In addition to the offense from Jones and Ewing, Duhon played a stellar floor game when the outcome was still in doubt. The junior point guard finished with eight points and nine assists, while Jones and Shelden Williams added 11 rebounds each. "I thought Duhon was magical in the second half with how he ran our team and kept us together,'' Krzyzewski said. "The passes he made when we went to a couple of different things to try to beat their pressure were pinpoint passes.'' Duke, which shot 68 percent in the second half, is 135-17 under Krzyzewski when ranked No. 1. The Blue Devils moved into the top slot in The Associated Press poll for the first time this season Monday. The victory set up a matchup of the nation's two unbeatens, as the Blue Devils host No. 17 Wake Forest (10-0) on Sunday night. Duke won despite going 20-for-36 from the foul line. "We showed that we're not mature yet,'' Krzyzewski said. "We were relaxing, we were glad we got a rest and we didn't concentrate as well. You can't leave those points on the court when you're playing outstanding teams.'' The Hoyas (8-2) were leading by five early in the second half, but got into trouble when Mike Sweetney, the sixth-leading scorer in the Big East at 19.9 a game, picked up fouls three and four in the opening 3:26 of the half and headed to the bench. He finished with 23, however Duke went for the kill with the Georgetown star out. Redick, Duke's leading scorer, was shut out in the opening period but started the decisive spurt with a baseline shot before Duhon made a driving layup. Duhon and Redick then sank consecutive 3-pointers in a span of 21 seconds and Duke was able to go up 58-49. "They hit those two big 3s that really got the crowd back involved in the game,'' Georgetown coach Craig Esherick said. "In the first half we did a good job of settling the crowd down and keeping them out of the game. "Mike has a good team. They are No. 1 for a reason. We have to learn from this.'' Jones and Ewing helped seal the program's 19th straight home win with 5:53 left. Jones blocked a breakaway dunk try by Tony Bethel, Ewing sank a spinning 3-pointer 20 seconds later and Jones made one from behind the 3-point arc on Duke's next possession. Duke's point total was 35 more than Georgetown had allowed per game. "I'm glad we've got a sixth man like we've got,'' Krzyzewski said of the Cameron Crazies. "Our students were amazing. They must all be excited to be back at school and start class. They were a huge, huge help. Cameron was hungry tonight and that's the way this team needs Cameron to be.'' Duke trailed at the half for the first time all season as the Hoyas used their size and quickness to claim a 44-41 lead. The Blue Devils were their own worst enemy in the opening 20 minutes as starting center Casey Sanders picked up three fouls in the first 6:40, Redick was 0-for-5 from the field and Duke missed nine of 15 free throws. It was the third time in his career that Jones, who was 9-for-12 from the field, scored 22. Ewing's previous best was 18 points earlier this season against Ohio State.
